1.text: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour is not seemly for a fool.

2.text: As the sparrow in her wandering, as the swallow in her flying, so the curse that is causeless lighteth not.

3.text: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the back of fools.

4.text: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.

6.text: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off his own feet, and drinketh in damage.

7.text: The legs of the lame hang loose: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.

8.text: As a bag of gems in a heap of stones, so is he that giveth honour to a fool.

9.text: As a thorn that goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the month of fools.

10.text: As an archer that woundeth all, so is he that hireth the fool and he that hireth them that pass by.

11.text: As a dog that returneth to his vomit, so is a fool that repeateth his folly.

12.text: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.

13.text: The sluggard saith, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.

14.text: As the door turneth upon its hinges, so doth the sluggard upon his bed.

15.text: The sluggard burieth his hand in the dish; it wearieth him to bring it again to his mouth.

16.text: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.

17.text: He that passeth by, and vexeth himself with strife belonging not to him, is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.

18.text: As a madman who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death;

19.text: So is the man that deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am not I in sport?

20.text: For lack of wood the fire goeth out: and where there is no whisperer, contention ceaseth.

21.text: As coals are to hot embers, and wood to fire; so is a contentious man to inflame strife.

22.text: The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

23.text: Fervent lips and a wicked heart are like an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross.

24.text: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, but he layeth up deceit within him:

25.text: When he speaketh fair, believe him not; for there are seven abominations in his heart:

26.text: Though his hatred cover itself with guile, his wickedness shall be openly shewed before the congregation.

27.text: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it shall return upon him.

28.text: A lying tongue hateth those whom it hath wounded; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.
